Intervention: The participants received standard support care as a packaged red blood cell transfusion (RCC) in accordance with the investigator's discretion.
Participants received SOC plus epoetin alfa 40,000 international units (IU) subcutaneously (SC) once a week.
Eligibility: Clinical evidence of metastasis (e.g. biopsy) with at least 1 measurable metastatic lesion (M1) prior to the start of current chemotherapy
There are plans to receive at least 2 additional chemotherapy cycles
Note from the Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group 0 or 1
At least 18 years of age using effective or surgically sterile or postmenopausal contraception for 1 year
No recent history of clinically significant thrombovascular event
A brain metastasis or CNS intervention
A recent use (in the previous 1 month) of an ESA
A progressive disease during adjuvant/neoadjuvant chemotherapy
A metastatic disease that is rapidly progressive or life-threatening
One patient with a local metastasis site and successfully treated surgically.
Results: Participants who had not progressed and were still alive at the time of the clinical cut-off were censored during the last assessment of the disease prior to the clinical cut-off. With respect to the PD or death with a missing interval immediately prior to the event, progression-free survival (PFS) was censored during the last assessment of the disease prior to the missing interval. Participants who withdrew from the study (withdrawal of consent or loss of follow-up) without progression were censored at the time of the last assessment of the disease.
Time limit: From date of randomization to date of disease progression (PD) or death, whichever occurs first (up to 8.4 years)
Name of Arm/Group: Standard of Care (SOC)
Description of the arm and group: Participants received standard support care in the form of packaged red blood cell transfusion (RBC) at the discretion of the investigator.
Title of the arm/group: Epoetin Alfa
Description of the arm/group: Participants received SOC plus epoetin alfa 40,000 international units (IU) subcutaneously (SC) once a week.
